column1: Metabolism is the set of life-sustaining chemical transformations within the cells of living organisms. The three main purposes of metabolism are the conversion of food/fuel to energy to run cellular processes
column2: the conversion of food/fuel to building blocks for proteins
column6: and the elimination of nitrogenous wastes. These enzyme-catalyzed reactions allow organisms to grow and reproduce
column8: and respond to their environments. The word metabolism can also refer to the sum of all chemical reactions that occur in living organisms
column9: including digestion and the transport of substances into and between different cells
column10: in which case the set of reactions within the cells is called intermediary metabolism or intermediate metabolism.Metabolism is usually divided into two categories: catabolism
column11: the breaking down of organic matter
column15: the building up of components of cells such as proteins and nucleic acids. Usually
column16: breaking down releases energy and building up consumes energy.
